description.narrative: Adequate policies on renewable energy in place, strong institutional linkages established, and knowledge, awareness and capacities of stakeholders improved

title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation: Sustainable Rural Biomass Energy Project

description.narrative: Reduction of GHG emissions in the rural household and industrial sectors of Bhutan through integrated and sustainable biomass resource production and promotion of sustainable biomass energy technologies

description.narrative:
1. Total Quantity of GHG emissions mitigated annually by End of Project (EOP), tCO2e: 196,700
2. Reduction of fuel-wood consumption for energy use in households and industries by EOP, tonnes: 183,200
3. Number of Enterprises supplying clean and efficient biomass energy systems and services by EOP: 3
4. Number of furnaces/stoves installed and used on a daily basis by households in targeted areas by EOP: 20,000
5. Number of community based fuelwood plantations being utilized by communities & households for use in BET applications by EOP: 50
6. Number of men/women trained and participating as technicians in the construction and installations of stoves: 20

Removal of barriers to sustainable utilization of available biomass resources in the country and application of biomass energy technologies that can support economic and social development in the countryâ€™s rural sector, in order to reduce GHG emissions.

comment.narrative: 111 hectares of plantation under SRBE project completed in 7 districts (in 45 community forests)

description.narrative: Implementation of BET applications due to improved confidence in their feasibility, performance, environmental and economic benefits through demonstration projects, market mechanisms and increased private sector participation

comment.narrative: At least 3
Implementation of Briquetting project under progress. Agreement reached for the implementation of briquetting project by the Association of Wood Based Industries.

description.narrative: Improved knowledge, awareness and capacities of policy makers, financiers, suppliers and end-users on benefits and market opportunities for modern biomass energy technologies
Number of participants trained in different aspects of biomass energy such as policy, financing, technology & market mechanisms by EOP.

comment.narrative: At least 200

Trained 334 (121 male and 213 Female) Non Formal Education Instructors in 16 Districts out of which 63.77 % are women.
Trained 78 (60 male and 18 Female) technicians by Bhutan Association of Women Entrepreneur (BAOWE) in Zhemgang, Tsirang and Dagana Districts
Trained 16 (15 Male and 1 Female) technicians by Tarayana Foundation in Sarpang District.
Trained 878 (321 female and 557 male) community forest management group members on sustainable fuel wood plantation with 37% female representation
Awareness created for more than 7,000 users in all 20 districts

title.narrative: Low Emission Capacity Building Project - Bhutan

description.narrative: Support national climate change mitigation efforts to reduce Green House Gas emissions and plan future low emission developmental activities
Preparation and Implementation of Bhutan’s Low Emission Capacity Building project

activity-description.narrative: GHG reduction through NAMAs in transport and municipal sold waste and LEDS developed for transport and Industries

description.narrative: • National environmental information systems enhanced with GHG inventory and National Forest Inventory process enabled to manage forest carbon data. • 3 NAMAs (Transport, Housing and Waste management) • 2 LEDS (transport and industries) • MRV systems in place for identified NAMAs and LEDS • NEC (CCD/NEC) and Multisectoral Technical Committee on Climate Change (MSTCCC) responding adequately to national and sectoral requirements for GHG inventory, mitigation analysis and strategy development.

comment.narrative: 2nd National communication National Environment strategy NAPA update Green house gas inventory 2000

1. Greenhouse gas inventory data management system developed 2. NAMA proposal on transport and municipal solid waste management developed 2.1 Carbon neutrality assessment completed 3. LEDS for Industries and transport developed 3.1 Vehicle emission standards revised 4. Capacity building in the NAMA and LEDS process including MRVS 5. Terminal Evaluation completed LECB enhanced support
1. Support TCC in review and update of urban design and structure plans with focus on pedestranization 2. ITS feasibility study completed and key recommendations initiated 3. Support Bhutan Post in improving the current transport system 4. Institutional capacity of key stakeholders strengthened

1. GHG Inventory data management systems developed 2. Draft NAMA transport and waste developed 3. Draft LEDS for transport and industries developed 3.1 Capacity building related to revision of the vehicle emission standards from 20-26 March 2015. The training was provided to a target group of officials who will be involved in the revision of vehicle emission standards.
LECBES 2. Intelligent transport systems study completed. Activities recommended through the study underway

description.narrative: INDC prepatation , senzitization and capacity building
Addressing the Risks of Climate-induced Disasters through Enhanced National and Local Capacity for Effective Actions
Addressing the Risks of Climate-induced Disasters through Enhanced National and Local Capacity for Effective Actions

1. No. of active landslides stabilized in Phuentsholing 2. No. of dzongkhags/municipalities with DM plan in place 3. No. of trained district/municipalities disaster response teams in place 4. No. of national and district level EOCs 5. No. of national level water resources inventory 6. No. of real-time automatic weather stations in the country 7. No. of flood monitoring stations in the country

To enhance national, local and community capacity to prepare for and respond to climate-induced multi-hazards to reduce potential losses of human lives, national economic infrastructure, livelihoods, and livelihood assets.

Level of capacity of local communities to prepare for and respond to climate-induced risks.
Availability of climate information and the level of their use for preparedness and reduction of impacts

comment.narrative:
* Local disaster mgt institutions functional in 16 of 20 dzongkhags
* Mock-drills not widely adopted except 1 # of mock-drills under LDCF GLOF project;
* No real-time localized weather data available to local institutions and communities
* No community-level seasonal water resources inventory available

Communities capacity to prepare for and respond to localized climate-induced risks enhanced :
* Existence of functional local disaster mgt institutions;
* Adequate response to scenario-based early earning mock-drills (4 no. in Years 3 and 4, in 4 dzongkhags)
* Availability of real-time localized weather data (measured in four sample dzongkhags)
* Availability of seasonal water resource inventory (measured in 5-6 gewogs)

District Disaster Management Committee capacitated through sensitization workshop on the existing institutional and legislative framework on disaster management in Bhutan.
All blocks in Chukha Dzongkhags have prepared their disaster management plans, resulting in raising awareness among communities, and empowering people to identify, prioritise and plan for climate -induced hazards.

description.narrative: Risk from climate-induced floods and landslides reduced in Bhutan’s economic and industrial center Phuentsholing and Pasakha Industrial Area.

comment.narrative:
Erosion in Barsa watershed and sedimentation and flooding in Barsa river is reduced due to comprehensive mitigation measures, reducing the occurrence of floods resulting in damages by 25%
Reduced annual cost of riverbed dredging in Pasakha Industrial Area by 30%
Four critical landslide sites in Phuentsholing-Rinchending area stabilized and contained within existing boundaries, safeguarding economic assets
Proportion of men in households that perceive landslides and floods as a major concern reduced by 30%
Proportion of women in households that perceive landslides and floods as a major concern reduced by 30%
Proportion of industrial units that perceive floods as a major concern reduced by 30%

Detail design and engineering solutions on landslide and flood mitigation measures being studied by a consortium of French (IMSRN) and local (APECS) consultants.
A technical manual for geo hazard and risk assessment and landslide mapping has been drafted and finalized.
Geological/geotechnical data collection for a critical landslide area in Moshi under Wamrong Dungkhag under Tashigang Dzongkhag completed.

description.narrative: Community resilience to climate-induced disaster risks (droughts, floods, landslides, windstorms, forest fires) strengthened in at least four dzongkhags.

Water resource inventories, water harvesting technology and additional water storage capacity available in some the most drought-prone communities of Bhutan
Existence and operationalization of disaster management committees at the local level

comment.narrative:
50 percent of the national water resources inventory data analysis has been completed.
Rehabilitation of Mongar Municipality’s water supply system ongoing.
Tarayana Foundation has initiated works to enable communities in project areas resilient to climate induced water stress.
A process for the establishment of community forest fire management groups and community forest fire planning has been developed.
A field manual and guidelines conducting community forest fire planning and establishing community forest fire management groups has been written. This covers using a participatory approach and facilitation skills as well as outlining in detail the process for community forest fire planning and the workshop activities.

description.narrative: Relevant information about climate-related risks and threats shared across development sectors for planning and preparedness on a timely and reliable basis.

comment.narrative:
The current network of meteorological stations is limited to 24 stations, of which only 3 are automated. Existing infrastructure for climate risk warning is highly GLOF-risk related.
The NWFFWC is in a nascent stage supported by a small network of meteorological stations and with insufficient capacity to analyze, manage, and disseminate climate information in a timely manner.
Demand for and use of localized climate information is yet unclear and undervalued
Due to sector fragmentation little exchange of knowledge, lessons and experiences takes place, existing platforms are shaped around national programmes (like NAPA working group) but do not function adequately outside the framework of these programmes due to limited capacity of NECS for multi-stakeholder process facilitation and sector leadership

Network with national coverage of minimum # 60 new real-time weather stations and # 45 new flood measurement stations established.
NWFFWC operational, with a core team of at least 10 members trained and established for climate data analysis, management and dissemination;
Climate data/ information user training provided to at least 100 staff of key data user agencies, e.g. disaster management, agriculture, forestry, hydropower, civil aviation, road transport, and tourism, and local government institutions.
Updated weather forecasting and localized climate information disseminated on a daily basis through web-portal, media and other means
At least three evidence-based policy influencing documents disseminated through NECS
National climate change policy framework in place (CC adaptation and synergies), with gender segregated policies and monitoring framework

Site verification and validation / land acquisition for establishment of 60 real-time Automatic Weather Stations completed.
Site development works for installation of AWS was contracted out for 19 AWS sites in western region.
Technical/sensor specification for AWS procurement being prepared (85% completed).
Site validation works including land acquisition for installation of real-time automatic water level station has been completed for 35 sites.
Education & Awareness Program on hydro-met data use/climate change and upcoming automatic weather and water level stations carried out in 4 districts (Haa, Chukha, Trongsa and Bumthang).
National Workshop was conducted to sensitize, educate and inform the various stakeholders on the use of hydro-met data on 10th-11th Oct, 2014 in Paro. There were 25 participants representing government agencies, Universities and private sector.
Engineers and hydro-met technicians have visited sites and validated the proposed sites for 60 AWS sites and 35 AWLS site throughout Bhutan over the period of about 6 months ( starting from August 2014).
A dialogue titled “Climate Resilient and Carbon Neutral Development” was organized to inform stakeholders on climate change action and activities in Bhutan.
